title: 112_hr2453
content: The "Mark Twain Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes Mark Twain's significant literary contributions, with his works translated into numerous languages and remaining in print to this day. His impact on American culture is evident through the continued interest in his life and work, with over 100 books and 250 doctoral dissertations dedicated to studying him in the past two decades. Mark Twain's work continues to be studied and celebrated today, with over 100 books published and 250 doctoral dissertations written on his life and work. Americans and people from around the world visit National Historic Landmarks dedicated to him, such as the Mark Twain House & Museum in Hartford, CT, and the Mark Twain Boyhood Home & Museum in Hannibal, MO. His work addresses social issues of the time, including the legacy of the Civil War and race relations. Educational institutions like the Mark Twain Project at the University of California, Berkeley, and the Center for Mark Twain Studies at Elmira College, NY, keep his legacy alive. Elmira College in New York will mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be numismatic items and have designs emblematic of Mark Twain's life and legacy. The design will include the coin's value, the year "2016", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees. The coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may only issue these coins during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2016. The sale price of the coins will include the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales of the coins will also be available. The Secretary will make bulk sales of coins at a discount and accept prepaid orders before issuance. Surcharges of $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin will be included in all sales, with a quarter of the surcharges going to the Mark Twain House & Museum in Hartford, Connecticut. The surcharges from the sales of coins will be distributed as follows: one-quarter to the University of California, Berkeley for the Mark Twain Project, one-quarter to Elmira College for research and education, one-quarter to the Mark Twain Boyhood Home and Museum in Hannibal, Missouri for preservation efforts. The Comptroller General of the United States will have auditing rights. The Secretary has the right to examine books, records, and documents related to expenditures of organizations mentioned in subsection (b). No surcharge can be included for issuing coins if it exceeds the annual limitation. The Secretary will ensure minting coins will not result in a net cost. The minting and issuing of coins under this Act will not cost the US Government. No funds are disbursed until the total cost of designing and issuing all authorized coins is recovered by the US Treasury.
